title: Tuesday’s Travel News and Tips
text:
Our weekday morning digest that includes consumer news, deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know.
MAMA COMES TO LOS ANGELES
A potential crosstown rival to the Ace Hotel Downtown Los Angeles, the cheap and chic European hotel chain Mama Shelter will open its first American property on Wednesday, July 8, with the 70-room Mama Shelter Hollywood .
Housed in the former Hotel Wilcox, one block from Sunset Boulevard, the new tenant aims to implant itself in the night-life scene with a 24-hour restaurant featuring comfort food dishes from the French chef Benjamin Bailly, whose résumé includes stints at the Hollywood Roosevelt Hotel and L’Atelier Robuchon. Over 100 artists have contributed artwork throughout the building including the chalkboard ceiling in the restaurant, an ongoing project featuring artwork inspired by their mothers.
Guests will have access to rental scooters and bikes as well as a rooftop fitness center, opening in September, inspired by the outdoor gyms on Venice Beach. Rooms start at $149 per night and include 27-inch iMacs that serve as both televisions and computers, and copies of screenplays based in Los Angeles such as “The Big Lebowski.”
Owned by the Trigano family, original developers of Club Med resorts, the boutique brand also operates in Paris, Marseille, Lyon, Bordeaux and Istanbul.
DIVE TO THE MUSIC
Rather than listening to their own Darth Vader-like breaths in the water, scuba divers at Looe Key in the Florida Keys National Marine Sanctuary can swim to music next Saturday, July 11, during the annual Lower Keys Underwater Music Festiva l.
From 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. Eastern time, the radio station WWUS, known as US1-Radio, will broadcast marine-themed hits like “Yellow Submarine” by the Beatles and “Fins” by Jimmy Buffett via underwater speakers from boats stationed at Looe Key Reef, roughly six miles south of Big Pine Key. At the surface, snorkelers can also catch the broadcast.
The one-day event, now in its 31st year, aims to highlight reef protection in a festive atmosphere that often draws divers costumed as mermaids, pirates or rock stars.
“It’s just one of the ways we celebrate our reef and reef preservation,” Gayle Tippet said, co-owner of Strike Zone Charters in Big Pine Key. The operator offers a 9 a.m. Eastern departure next Saturday to catch the festival, costing $38 for snorkelers and $48 for divers, before equipment.
PAN AM PARTIES IN TORONTO
While the 2015 Women’s World Cup matches hopscotched around Canada, the six-city circuit skipped Toronto, which was busy preparing for its own moment in the sports spotlight with the Pan Am Games , beginning Friday, July 10, and running through July 26.

Continue reading the main story The third largest international multisport games, after the Olympics and the Asian Games, will draw over 7,000 athletes from 41 countries and territories throughout North, Central and South America. The games are held every four years, in the year before the Olympics, and include 36 events including archery, swimming, track and field and wrestling.
Organizers say tickets are still available, and that a host of hotels are offering availability throughout the competition, including the Hilton Toronto with an average nightly rate of 219 Canadian dollars (about $180).
The event, and the Parapan American Games that follow it starting on Aug. 7, has sparked a series of festivals in the city, including Panamania , a 35-day arts and culture festival with over 250 scheduled theater, music and dance performances from July 10 through Aug. 15. During Summerlicious , from July 3 to 26, over 200 participating restaurants will feature dishes inspired by the 41 Pan Am nations. Ontario’s Celebration Zone at Toronto’s Harbourfront Center will serve as a central gathering area for fans including a free zip line, climbing wall, daily culinary events such as cook-offs and nightly concerts.
OFF-ROADING AMONG THE VINES
The gush of grapes planted in Michigan’s Leelanau Peninsula has attracted an influx of wine tourists who can newly tour the rolling region off-road via a guided mountain bike tasting.
Grand Traverse Bike Tours in Suttons Bay has introduced a Cycle the Vineyards Tour , an eight-to-10-mile mountain bike trip that follows mostly off-road trails, including the opportunity to pedal through the vines at one vineyard. The tour visits two different wineries for tastings and a support van trails the group to pick up any wines purchased.
The Saturday tours run through Oct. 3 and cost $79 per person, including a bike and picnic lunch. On other days the company offers a self-guided tour along the Leelanau Peninsula Wine Trail ($59 per person) that sticks mostly to pavement.
